source_id: STP1543-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_17th Volume_010_chunk1
evidence_span: Cast $Z r { - } 2 . 5 N b$ was hot-deformed in the temperature range of $7 0 0 ^ { \circ } \mathsf C$ to $\bar { 1 } \bar { 1 } 0 0 ^ { \circ } \mathsf C$ and in the strain-rate range of $1 0 ^ { - 3 }$ to $1 0 { \varsigma } ^ { - 1 }$ using compression tests.

source_id: STP1543-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_17th Volume_010_chunk1
evidence_span: The map showed a single domain that spanned the temperature range from $8 0 0 ^ { \circ } \mathsf { C }$ to ${ 1 1 0 0 ^ { \circ } C }$ and strain rates less than $0 . 1 \mathsf { s } ^ { - 1 }$

source_id: STP1543-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_17th Volume_010_chunk1
evidence_span: with a peak strain rate sensitivity of 0.3 at $1 0 0 0 ^ { \circ } \mathsf C$ and $1 0 ^ { - 3 } \ s ^ { - 1 }$

source_id: STP1543-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_17th Volume_010_chunk1
evidence_span: At low temperatures $7 0 0 ^ { \circ } \mathsf C$ and $7 5 0 ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C } )$ and high strain rates of 1 and $1 0 { \mathsf { s } } ^ { - 1 }$ , some macroscopic flow localization was observed.

source_id: STP1543-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_17th Volume_010_chunk1
evidence_span: the cast structure could be safely broken in both the $\alpha + \beta$ and $\beta$ phases when deformed at strain rates less than $0 . 1 \mathsf { s } ^ { - 1 }$

source_id: STP1543-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_17th Volume_010_chunk1
evidence_span: $\mathrm { Z r } { - } 2 . 5 \mathrm { N b }$ is used as a pressure tube material for structural components in nuclear pressurized heavy water reactors.

source_id: STP1543-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_17th Volume_010_chunk1
evidence_span: the first extrusion of the cast structure being in the $\alpha + \beta$ field.

source_id: STP1543-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_17th Volume_010_chunk1
evidence_span: in both the optimum hot-working domain was around $8 0 0 ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C }$ and $1 0 ^ { - 3 } \ s ^ { - 1 }$

evidence_span: Compression tests were carried out to a true strain of 0.7, with some tests conducted to a true strain of about 1.6

source_id: STP1543-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_17th Volume_010_chunk7
evidence_span: Zirconium alloys are extensively used in various types of fission reactors such as light and heavy water based reactors as the proven structural material on account of good high temperature mechanical properties and low neutron absorption cross-section

source_id: STP1543-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_17th Volume_010_chunk7
evidence_span: low neutron absorption cross-section

source_id: STP1543-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_17th Volume_010_chunk7
evidence_span: the fuel assemblies are placed inside tubes of $\mathrm { Z r } { - } 2 . 5 \mathrm { N b }$ alloy which form the primary pressure boundary

source_id: STP1543-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_17th Volume_010_chunk7
evidence_span: These pressure tubes experience a high degree of mechanical stresses along with the irradiation induced damage from high neutron flux for a prolonged period of time

source_id: STP1543-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_17th Volume_010_chunk7
evidence_span: the tubes need to have appropriate texture and microstructure to resist the harsh service environment

source_id: STP1543-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_17th Volume_010_chunk7
evidence_span: the tubes need to have appropriate texture and microstructure to resist the harsh service environment

evidence_span: Typically textural and microstructural control is achieved by appropriate thermomechanical fabrication processing

source_id: STP1543-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_17th Volume_010_chunk7

source_id: STP1543-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_17th Volume_010_chunk7
evidence_span: the crystallographic texture produced during the hot extrusion stage largely remains unaltered even after further cold work

source_id: STP1543-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_17th Volume_010_chunk10
evidence_span: The temperature variation across the length is much more than across the section at lower ram velocities

source_id: STP1543-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_17th Volume_010_chunk12
evidence_span: Lower ram velocities were found to result in appreciable temperature loss at the tailing end, thus giving rise to more leading end to tailing end variation

source_id: STP1543-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_17th Volume_010_chunk12
evidence_span: higher ram velocities were found to increase the variation across the thickness

source_id: STP1543-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_17th Volume_010_chunk12
evidence_span: Higher reduction ratios were found to increase the temperature gradients across the thickness due to increased strain gradients at die profile side

source_id: STP1543-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_17th Volume_010_chunk12
evidence_span: Frictional heating at the die profile was found to be more substantial than the temperature drop due to mandrel chilling effect

source_id: STP1543-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_17th Volume_010_chunk12
evidence_span: peak force of extrusion is stronger function of the ram velocity than the steady state force

source_id: STP1543-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_17th Volume_010_chunk12
evidence_span: using of higher preheat temperature will have beneficial effect in terms of overall homogeneity

source_id: STP1543-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_17th Volume_010_chunk12

evidence_span: The copper jacketing used on Zr-2.5Nb extrusion is for protection against oxidation

source_id: STP1543-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_17th Volume_010_chunk12
evidence_span: For lubrication purposes, oil based graphite lubricant is used

source_id: STP1543-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_17th Volume_010_chunk13
evidence_span: The role of microstructure during the deformation on the texture development has been investigated in detail

source_id: STP1543-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_17th Volume_010_chunk13
evidence_span: texture development is influenced by variables like temperature of deformation, reduction ratio, nature of working (extrusion or forging at elevated temperature and pilgering/drawing at ambient temperature), ratio of wall thickness to o.d. reduction (Q-ratio), and heat-treatment

evidence_span: Thin foils were examined in a PEM430T (FEI Electron Optics Eindhoven, Netherlands) TEM operating at $3 0 0 \mathrm { k V }$

Cu $\mathrm { K } \alpha$ $\lambda = 0 . 1 5 4 \mathrm { n m }$ radiation from an X-ray tube operating at $3 0 \mathrm { k V }$ and $3 0 \mathrm { m A }$ was used as the source

source_id: STP1543-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_17th Volume_010_chunk14
evidence_span: three ingot processing methods were used to manufacture the tubes

source_id: STP1543-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_17th Volume_010_chunk14
evidence_span: the ingots were hot extruded in the two-phase $\alpha + \beta$ phase region to billet size and then $\beta$ quenched at $1 0 0 0 ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C }$

source_id: STP1543-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_17th Volume_010_chunk14
evidence_span: the ingots were hot forged to an intermediate size and then $\beta$ quenched

source_id: STP1543-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_17th Volume_010_chunk14
evidence_span: The first forging was carried out in the single-phase $\beta$ region, whereas the second forging was done in the two-phase $\alpha + \beta$ region

source_id: STP1543-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_17th Volume_010_chunk14
evidence_span: After the second forging the billets were air-cooled and machined

source_id: STP1543-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_17th Volume_010_chunk14
evidence_span: Route 3 was identical to route 2, except that the $\beta$ quenching step was carried out after the second hot forging

source_id: STP1543-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_17th Volume_010_chunk14
evidence_span: Billets from these three methods were hot extruded and processed using two different extrusion ratios (ER) in stage 2

source_id: STP1543-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_17th Volume_010_chunk14
evidence_span: the extruded tube hollows were processed to tubes using two-stage pilgering route with an intermediate anneal (process routes 1a and 2), single stage pilgering (route 3) and by following a thermo-mechanical processing route with $\alpha + \beta$ quenching and ageing (route 1b)

conditions.route_1b: thermo-mechanical processing with α+β quenching and ageing

source_id: STP1543-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_17th Volume_010_chunk32
evidence_span: Coating methods and coating materials that could be used to reduce the oxidation rate of zirconium-based alloy in a high-temperature steam environment were studied.

source_id: STP1543-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_17th Volume_010_chunk32
evidence_span: Regarding the coating materials tested at a $1 2 0 0 ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C }$ in steam environment, the $\mathrm { S i O } _ { 2 }$ showed the greatest oxidation resistance among the tested materials

source_id: STP1543-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_17th Volume_010_chunk32
evidence_span: Si was more effective than $\mathrm { C r }$ in terms of oxidation resistance.

source_id: STP1543-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_17th Volume_010_chunk32
evidence_span: The PS coating technique has problems, such as the formation of pores in the Si-coated layer and interface oxidation caused by low adhesion during the hightemperature oxidation test at $1 2 0 0 ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C } .$

source_id: STP1543-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_17th Volume_010_chunk32
evidence_span: the pores in the Si-coated layer were successfully removed, and the interface oxidation was suppressed by the formation of diffusion bonding between the Zircaloy-4 substrate and the $\mathrm { S i - Z r }$ mixed layer.

source_id: STP1543-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_17th Volume_010_chunk32
evidence_span: the oxidation resistance of the $\mathrm { S i - Z r }$ mixed layer was superior to that of Zircaloy-4, and good adhesion was obtained.

source_id: STP1543-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_17th Volume_010_chunk32
evidence_span: the hydrogen generation of zirconium alloy undergoing excess oxidation in a hightemperature steam environment can be considerably reduced by the application of Si coating via $\mathrm { P S } + \mathrm { L B S }$ technology.

source_id: STP1543-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_17th Volume_010_chunk32
evidence_span: the coated cladding will be tested in the in-pile condition, as well as in a severe oxidation test such as a steam condition and in mixed conditions between steam and air at temperatures higher than $1 2 0 0 ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C } .$

source_id: STP1543-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_17th Volume_010_chunk32
evidence_span: the surface-modified cladding will be evaluated for various items such as bursting and ballooning and oxidation of the inner surface of the cladding to simulate the integrated physical properties during loss-of-coolant accidents.
test_type: bursting test, ballooning test, oxidation test
